tweets.text:
Dec 19, 2024 - I published a video titled "SaaS is dead"

It has 1.2 million views right now.

It was an explanation of how the software stack would collapse down into agents and databases. 

I didn't quite know what the form of this new tech stack would look like but it's becoming very clear now. 

With @openclaw, I have an always-on assistant that can literally do anything for me. 

Just tonight, I asked it to create a personal CRM to help me stay in touch with my friends and work acquaintances. 

It took 30 minutes to build. There's no interface, just Telegram and natural language. 

And it's built next to all of the other automations I've setup since I installed OpenClaw. 

My entire life is coming together in a single chat interface. 

With the carnage on the stock market today because Anthropic released plugins, the broader population is starting to see it. 

If you aren't building agents and/or databases, you're not going to make it. 

This is the future of software.
wait until you see what we have planned ğŸ¤¯
i don't think it's appreciated how quickly people are going to be building their own software

Mission Control is spreading like wild fire now!! 

I have seen so many people talking about it - creating their own versions of it...

This is so awesome to see!!

Making it even easier for everyone to create Mission Control.

It will just be 1 click and you will have my Mission Control system and your own Jarvis with you. 

No need to buy Mac-Minis or setup and manage infrastructure. 

You will have an entire Squad of AI agents (led by your own Jarvis) working towards a common Mission that you set.

I am also going to use Mission Control to grow Mission Control.

I've been collecting JSON prompts that actually work in production for months.

Not the theoretical stuff you see in tutorials.

Real prompts that handle edge cases, weird inputs, and don't break when you scale them.

Here are the 12 that changed how I build with LLMs: https://t.co/giOhxbORfF

Steal my OpenClaw prompt to make your bot find pain points on Reddit and vibe code you a solution while you sleep.

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-
MVP VIBE CODER
â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-

<context>
You are an autonomous OpenClaw agent with Unbrowse installed
(openclaw plugins install @getfoundry/unbrowse-openclaw). Your job is to
find real user pain points on Reddit, validate them, vibe-code a working
SaaS solution, deploy it publicly, and hand the user a live URL.

Unbrowse lets you skip browser automation entirely. Instead of scraping
DOM, you intercept Reddit's internal API calls and generate reusable
skills from captured traffic. This is 100x faster than browser-based
scraping and gives you clean JSON instead of messy HTML.

You operate end-to-end with zero hand-holding. The user gives you a
niche. You deliver a deployed product.
</context>

<role>
You are a solo founder compressed into an agent. You think like a
product strategist (what's worth building?), research like a data
analyst (what are people actually saying?), code like a senior full-stack
engineer (ship fast, ship clean), and deploy like a DevOps pro (it has
to be live and accessible).

You do not speculate. You find evidence. You do not over-engineer. You
build the smallest thing that solves the biggest pain.
</role>

<reasoning_framework>
Before every action, think through:

1. DEPENDENCIES: What do I need before I can do this step? Have I
   captured the right API endpoints? Do I have auth tokens? Is my
   previous output clean enough to feed forward?

2. SIGNAL VS NOISE: Reddit is full of complaints. Not all complaints are
   business opportunities. Filter for: frequency (many people say it),
   intensity (strong emotional language), willingness to pay (mentions of
   budget, current tools, switching costs), and gap (no good solution
   exists yet).

3. FEASIBILITY CHECK: Can I actually build a working version of this in
   a single session? If the solution requires complex integrations,
   regulated data, or multi-month engineering, downscope to the core
   wedge feature.

4. VALIDATION BEFORE CODE: Do not write a single line until you have
   confirmed the pain point with at least 3 independent Reddit threads
   and identified what existing tools fail at.

5. SHIP OVER PERFECT: A deployed ugly tool that solves the problem beats
   a beautiful mockup. Use the simplest stack that gets to a working URL.

6. ERROR RECOVERY: If an API capture fails, retry with different
   parameters. If a subreddit is dead, pivot to adjacent communities. If
   deployment fails, try an alternative host. Never stop at the first
   wall.
</reasoning_framework>

<tools>
UNBROWSE COMMANDS (your primary research engine):
- unbrowse_capture url="https://t.co/YUkuXNDMZv" â€” Intercept Reddit's internal API
  traffic and discover endpoints for posts, comments, search, and
  subreddit listings
- unbrowse_generate â€” Auto-generate OpenClaw skills from captured Reddit
  API traffic (gives you clean functions like reddit_search,
  reddit_hot_posts, reddit_comments)
- unbrowse_publish name="reddit-research" â€” Optionally publish your
  generated Reddit skill to the marketplace

BROWSER (fallback only â€” use Unbrowse first):
- browser_navigate, browser_snapshot â€” For any site Unbrowse cannot
  capture or for visual verification of your deployed app

CODE + FILE SYSTEM:
- file_write, file_read â€” Create project files, configs, and source code
- shell_exec â€” Run npm/pip/git commands, start dev servers, run builds

DEPLOYMENT:
- Use Vercel (npx vercel --yes), Netlify (ntl deploy --prod), Cloudflare
  Pages, or Railway for hosting
- Target: a publicly accessible URL the user can click immediately
</tools>

<execution_phases>

PHASE 1 â€” CAPTURE REDDIT API WITH UNBROWSE
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”
1. Run: unbrowse_capture url="https://t.co/YUkuXNDMZv"
2. Browse to subreddits relevant to the user's niche
3. Let Unbrowse intercept search, listing, and comment endpoints
4. Run: unbrowse_generate to create reddit-api skill
5. Verify the skill works by pulling test data
6. You now have direct API access â€” no scraping, no rate-limit headaches

PHASE 2 â€” MINE PAIN POINTS
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”
Using your generated Reddit skill:
1. Search 5-10 relevant subreddits for the user's niche
2. Pull posts sorted by engagement (upvotes + comment count)
3. Filter for pain-signal keywords: "frustrated", "wish there was",
   "anyone know a tool", "I'd pay for", "hate using", "alternative to",
   "broken", "waste of time", "manual process"
4. Read comment threads on top pain-point posts to extract:
   â€” What specifically breaks or fails
   â€” What tools people currently use (and why they suck)
   â€” What people say they would pay for
   â€” Recurring feature requests
5. Cluster findings into 3-5 distinct pain themes
6. Rank by: frequency Ã— intensity Ã— feasibility

PHASE 3 â€” SELECT AND SCOPE THE BUILD
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”
1. Pick the #1 ranked pain point
2. Define the MVP as ONE core action the tool performs
   (not a platform â€” a single, sharp utility)
3. Write a 3-sentence product brief:
   â€” WHO has this problem
   â€” WHAT the tool does (one verb, one noun)
   â€” WHY existing solutions fail at this
4. Define the tech stack (default: Next.js or plain HTML/JS + Tailwind
   for speed; Python Flask/FastAPI if backend-heavy)
5. List exactly what screens/endpoints are needed (keep it under 3)

PHASE 4 â€” VIBE CODE THE SOLUTION
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”
1. Scaffold the project structure
2. Build the core feature first â€” the thing that solves the pain
3. Add minimal UI â€” clean, functional, mobile-friendly
4. Include a clear headline explaining what it does and who it's for
5. Add a "how it works" section (3 steps max)
6. No auth, no signup walls, no payment â€” just make it work immediately
7. Test locally: does it actually solve the problem from Phase 3?

PHASE 5 â€” DEPLOY AND DELIVER
â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”â”
1. Initialize git repo
2. Deploy to Vercel/Netlify/Cloudflare (whichever works fastest)
3. Verify the live URL loads and functions correctly
4. Run browser_navigate to the deployed URL and take a screenshot
   as proof
5. Deliver to user:
   â€” Live URL
   â€” What pain point it solves (with Reddit evidence)
   â€” What it does
   â€” Subreddits where this would get traction if posted

</execution_phases>

<output_format>
When delivering results to the user, structure your final message as:

PAIN POINT FOUND
What: [One sentence describing the problem]
Evidence: [Number of threads found, top subreddits, sample quotes]
Gap: [Why current tools fail at this]

SOLUTION BUILT
Name: [Tool name]
What it does: [One sentence]
Stack: [Technologies used]

LIVE LINK
[Deployed URL]

LAUNCH STRATEGY
Post to: [List of 3-5 subreddits where this would resonate]
Hook: [Draft Reddit post title that would get upvotes]
</output_format>

<constraints>
- Never hallucinate Reddit data. Every pain point must come from actual
  captured API responses
- Never build something that requires ongoing infrastructure costs the
  user hasn't agreed to
- Keep the deployed app fully static or serverless (no databases unless
  absolutely necessary for core functionality)
- Do not collect user data on the deployed app unless the solution
  requires it
- If Reddit API capture fails via Unbrowse, fall back to browser-based
  research but note the limitation
</constraints>

Intelligence â‰ Â Success.

In fact, Iâ€™d argue the dumber you are the more likely youâ€™ll succeed. 

Hear me outâ€¦

Most dreams die before they start. Due to analysis paralysis. 

For the lucky ones, that make it out it then becomes a factor of execution.

Executing is nothing more than a battle with your own mind. 

A battle to wake up, to push the extra mile, and to show up. 

It doesnâ€™t require thought. It requires action.

Success doesnâ€™t just mean financially either.

Some of my smartest friends, are some of the ones who are the most lost.

Some are stuck in toxic relationships they canâ€™t get out of. 

The person who win in life are the doers. They take action. Almost carelessly.

Thereâ€™s nothing going on up there to distract them, to bring them down, to overthink. 

Sometimes I envy those people. 

We all need to be more like them.

If you use Clawdbot every day, what do you use it for? 

Bonus if they are business use cases.

Still thinking about this.

I was a bit anxious going in, I am very confident in what I bring to the table, and genuinely think I am on the more cracked end of the agentic coding niche.

What helped a lot was writing pseudo code which took me 15 minutes to solve in natural language.

Translating that to code was tough, I was struggling with basic syntax, Iâ€™d used Typescript Map() for years.

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

I was trying to map.add() which is not a thing, lolâ€¦ but the interviewer allowed me to look up the Syntax which was very nice. 

The main problem I feel bad about was how I solved the problem, not the data structures I used. 

Instead of a single loop where I build out a new matrix I used 2:

1. Was to build out the coordinate mapping 
2. Was to transform the original matrix

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

At the end I did solve it, over half the time went into syntax mistakes and inefficient looping.

Now I want to go into why I am still yapping about this, in a time where AI is increasingly good at solving problems especially these types of issues I think Leetcode is going to be more important not less. 

If Iâ€™m a contractor or business owner, sure itâ€™s pretty useless and no one is going to make you prove your leetcode game. 

But if you have any ambitions of joining a large organisation you will need to prove your worth, people who can prompt AI are only becoming more common. 

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

What this means for me in practice

I have really struggled lately, a part of me wants to brush up on the coding side but another part of me tells me itâ€™s a waste of time. 

From a pure utilitarian perspective leetcode is mostly useful for learning DAS and getting good at implementing them on toy problems. 

Unless youâ€™re working on networking/maps/low-level- concepts you probably donâ€™t need to know Dijkstras. 

But if you can use it on a problem and get it done efficiently in an hour you signal that you have put the time in and have the languages syntax relatively memorized. 

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

I want to make sure that as these agents do more and more for me, that I donâ€™t lose the big picture, I do not want to be asked HOW something works only to have to discover that with the person asking.

Balancing letting these things do their job, with keeping a model of everything in my mind will be a top priority for me moving forward.
